report_title: Metal Pipe and Tube Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Through the current period, metal pipe and tube manufacturing revenue has expanded alongside volatile commodity prices and elevated inflation. The pandemic also hindered metal pipe and tube manufacturers, creating contractions in construction and manufacturing markets. Despite these challenges, manufacturers reaped strong growth in 2022 as steel prices climbed. Slight declines in revenue in recent years reflect cooling demand and inflation. Metal pipe and tube manufacturing revenue is forecast to rise at a CAGR of 0.2% to $17.1 billion through the end of 2024, including a 0.2% decline during the current year. Industry profit is expected to remain fairly steady despite faltering revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers heavily rely on oil and natural gas extraction
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Manufacturers rely on crude oil prices; one of the largest revenue sources by product segment is the oil country tubular goods (OCTG) product segment. OCTG pipes represent a family of pipes and tubes primarily used in oil drilling operations and pipeline construction. Oil and gas markets struggle to substitute metal pipes and tubes with plastic or concrete pipes; manufacturers specifically build metal pipes and tubes to withstand the highly corrosive and high-pressure environments that characterize oil and gas extraction projects.

Metal pipe and tube manufacturers heavily rely on commodity prices, as manufacturers rely on ferrous metals to make new products. Similarly, key oil and natural gas markets and suppliers rely on favorable crude oil prices. Supply chain disruptions have created significant instability for manufacturing during and following the pandemic. Steel prices skyrocketed in 2021 and 2022 as suppliers struggled to meet resurgent demand. Similarly, the Russian invasion of Ukraine led to major sanctions on Russian oil and steel, exacerbating supply chain concerns.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pipe demand from construction activity is highly volatile
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Metal pipe and tube manufacturing also heavily relies on demand from construction projects, particularly utility construction and heavy engineering projects. Household and nonresidential projects also use metal pipes, but plastic pipes often fill the same niche at lower costs, encouraging manufacturers to focus on utility markets. Construction markets struggled following the pandemic as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to combat rampant inflation. As interest rates skyrocketed, companies grew wary of major spending projects, preferring to postpone new construction.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Imports remain strong despite trade restrictions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Imports have mainly climbed due to higher steel prices, more robust domestic demand for welded steel pipe and the elimination of supply chain issues. The trade-weighted index's notable jump in 2022 has made imports more affordable in domestic markets. The United States has attempted to mitigate imports through trade restrictions, including antidumping and countervailing duties, imposed on certain metal pipes imported from countries like South Korea and Turkey. These measures have faced limited success, especially as the economy recovers from the pandemic and foreign producers rush to fill demand shortages.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Downstream manufacturing markets are moving production overseas
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The manufacturing sector as a whole will steadily grow as the economy recovers from the pandemic, generating demand for small-diameter pressure and mechanical tubing used in automotive parts, heating and air conditioning equipment and industrial machinery. Even so, downstream manufacturers have increasingly started to move production overseas. As these customers move abroad, they will source inputs from nearby suppliers in foreign markets instead of domestic manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Imported goods siphon demand away from domestic manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite strong domestic demand for tubular products, all segments continue to endure external competition from imported goods and substitute products. In particular, low-cost importers in Mexico and South Korea will pose a major threat to domestic manufacturers. Many manufacturers will rely more on custom-order and niche markets, such as specialized manufacturers and resource extraction companies, enabling them to differentiate from generic metal tubes and pipes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Substitutes will threaten demand in certain downstream markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Structural pipe and tubing manufacturers used in waterworks and construction applications will face direct challenges from external competitors, primarily plastic pipe and parts manufacturers. These products are commonly less expensive than metal pipes and tubes. Climbing product substitution will constrain performance as more downstream markets switch from metal pipes to those made from high-density polyethylene, polyvinyl chloride and other durable plastic materials.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Changing regulations threaten oil and gas markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Environmental regulations and social pressure have threatened oil and natural gas extraction in the United States. For example, the Biden administration has paused several oil and gas leases on federal lands and waters. Instead, current spending has focused on green energy production, leading to the utility sector's diminishing reliance on metal pipes and tubes and the economy's need for oil and natural gas.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry are standalone producers that manufacture welded, riveted and seamless pipes or tubes from purchased iron or steel. Consequently, steel is purchased as a primary input material in the metal pipe and tube manufacturing process.

key_trends: Competitive pricing attracts customers in the low-margin metal pipe and tube industry. Manufacturers must offer a variety of high-quality products to stay competitive. Balancing cost and quality is crucial for maintaining market position.

Having a diverse product line at various price points is crucial. Low-cost imports continuously threaten domestic manufacturers' profits. Offering a range of products helps mitigate this threat and sustain profitability in a competitive market.
During the pandemic, reduced consumption led to sharp declines in oil prices and decreased demand from resource extraction markets. This significant drop reshaped the economic landscape.

Infrastructure spending has bolstered demand from utility markets, but federal policy has threatened oil and natural gas production. This dynamic reflects the complexities influencing the sector's stability.
Many manufacturers are moving production offshore to reduce costs and position supply chains closer to essential buyers located in Asia. This trend highlights cost-driven global manufacturing shifts.

For example, the oil and gas markets demand highly specialized products, resulting in more custom orders and greater specialization. This trend underscores the industry's need for tailored solutions and expertise.
For instance, US Steel Corp maximizes efficiency through vertical integration, particularly with their tubular product subsidiaries. This strategy streamlines production and reduces costs.
Key regulations include the Clean Water Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, the Clean Air Act, the Cluster Rule and noise control mandates. Compliance is essential for operation.
Protective measures like anti-dumping and countervailing duties have supported US metal tube and pipe makers. These actions aim to counteract unfair trade practices and stabilize the market.
Volatile raw material prices have pressured profit, leading to higher purchasing costs for companies without long-term supply contracts. Effective material sourcing remains crucial.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Metal pipe and tube manufacturers serving the waterworks and construction markets have endured intense competition from plastic pipe and parts manufacturers, especially in residential and nonresidential construction markets. Plastic pipes are less expensive than comparable metal pipes, with lower maintenance costs and better corrosion resistance. Still, metal pipes and tubing remain superior products in regard to overall durability, limiting the power of substitutes. Even so, demand from utility construction markets has skyrocketed alongside new infrastructure spending. Similarly, the relative weakness of mining, oil and gas industries has enabled construction markets to rapidly expand.

This segment includes all markets associated with the oil and gas sector, including oil drilling and gas extraction, petroleum refining and oil pipeline transportation. Energy markets purchase line pipe, OCTG and pressure tubing. Power generation companies purchase a variety of tubular products used in heat recovery steam generators, moisture separator reheaters, steam turbines and other equipment. Demand from the oil and gas market is particularly volatile, driven by domestic and international drilling activity, private investment in oil and gas distribution networks and noneconomic factors, like geopolitical influences and changing environmental and energy regulations. The current administration has dissuaded new oil and natural gas drilling projects, limiting demand from this market.

Several industrial manufacturers rely on metal pipe and tube products. In aerospace, metal tubes ensure high resistance to extreme conditions. Metal pipe and tube products are in landing gears, motor shafts or exhaust stacks. In heavy engineering for commercial and residential construction, engineers use steel tubes for stairways and railings and in support structures throughout buildings. Metal pipe and tube products also have applications in medical equipment, automobiles and other highly technical industries. This market's diversity creates steady and varied revenue, enabling multiple companies to successfully manage niche markets. This market will expand as the economy, especially interest rates, recover, enabling more spending on vehicles, construction projects and other heavy engineering projects.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Oil and Natural Gas Price Index
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The oil and natural gas price index acts as a proxy for demand from the oil and gas producers, the industry's largest market. As the oil and natural gas price index increases, oil and gas exploration increases as extraction operations become more profitable. As oil and gas exploration increases, demand for metal pipe and tube products will rise.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Manufacturers Endure a Major Trade Deficit
international_trade_points.trade_description: Since the late 1990s, the industry has imported more than it exports. This trade deficit has widened following the US dollar's appreciation through the current period. Strong domestic demand and a strong US dollar have boosted total imports, trends that have characterized the market landscape throughout the current period. Asian manufacturers, specifically South Korean and Japanese producers, have played an increasing role in trade markets.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Regulations and Commodity Prices Influence Import Volumes
international_trade_points.trade_description: Antidumping and countervailing duties imposed following Federal Trade Commission (FTC) investigations have limited imports. These actions have supported the domestic industry, artificially making domestic products more competitive. The commodity crash amid the pandemic slashed import volumes as domestic oil producers shut down unprofitable operations. Import penetration plummeted in 2020 before rebounding in the following years.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Close Proximity to Canada and Mexico Benefits Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports represent a moderate share of industry revenue. The largest destinations for exported metal pipe and tubing products are Canada and Mexico due to their proximity to the United States and Canada's increasing dependence on imported manufactured goods. These countries have benefited from the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which reduces trade barriers within North America. These regions have become increasingly prevalent trade partners.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The US Dollar's Growth Hinders Export Markets
international_trade_points.trade_description: A strong US dollar has made domestic metal pipes and tubes more expensive in foreign markets. The US dollar's growth, represented by the trade-weighted index (TWI), has slashed exports through the current period. Export markets will recover through the outlook period as the TWI depreciates. This trend will enable manufacturers to create more sustainable growth.

business_locations.location_description: The presence of iron and steel suppliers in the Southeast is responsible for the distribution of pipe and tube manufacturers in this region. This region is home to many manufacturing industries, resulting in a consistent customer base. The region also has a strong population, leading to more robust downstream manufacturing and construction activity.

Automotive companies use metal pipe and tube products in their vehicles. The Big Three US auto manufacturers, General Motors, Ford and Stellantis, are based in Michigan. A significant amount of other manufacturing activity occurs in the region, making it a suitable location. Many key steel and iron producers are also in the Great Lakes region.

The Southwest region attracts pipe and tube manufacturers due to its notable customer base, especially in the niche oil and gas industries. Large demand segments from Texas are related to oil refining and drilling industries, which purchase goods from metal pipe and tube manufacturers.
This region is vital for business due to its proximity to large population centers, offering a strategic location for trade and distribution.
The Western region offers access to key markets and has a growing demand for metal pipes and tubes, primarily due to its construction industry.
This region has been important for mining industries, which also rely heavily on metal pipes and tubes.
The Plains region is known for agricultural and energy industries, creating a continual demand for metal products.
New England holds a mix of industrial and service-based economies, boosting the demand for infrastructure-related metal products.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The metal pipe and tube manufacturing industry faces stringent local and state zoning requirements. Additionally, manufacturers need environmental permits subject to changes, renewals, or revocation.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Clean Water Act (CWA) and The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Metal pipe manufacturers must adhere to the stringent discharge procedures outlined by the Clean Water Act (CWA) and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). These regulations govern water and solid waste management and include provisions for airborne pollution.
The Clean Air Act (CAA) significantly impacts the metal pipe manufacturing industry by imposing strict limits on carbon monoxide, nitrous oxides, sulfur oxides and particulates.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) governs the release and remediation of hazardous substances within the metal pipe manufacturing industry.
OSHA enforces regulations that limit noise levels and dust exposure in the metal pipe manufacturing industry to safeguard worker health.
Environmental and zoning regulations significantly impact the metal pipe manufacturing industry. Both local and state governments enforce these rules, affecting where and how manufacturers operate.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975
regulations_points.regulation_description: The 1975 Energy Policy and Conservation Act initially banned the export of domestically produced crude oil. However, Congress lifted this ban amid a severe downturn in oil prices, allowing US oil producers to enter global markets.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry has high and steady competition.

factors_increased_barrier: Metal pipe and tube manufacturers must comply with strict environmental laws covering noise pollution, solid waste emissions and treatment. Quality standards imposed by private organizations also demand adherence, adding another layer of regulatory complexity for new entrants.

Entering the metal pipe manufacturing industry involves significant start-up costs, including investments in large-scale production facilities and equipment. These capital expenses are necessary to achieve economies of scale and manufacturing efficiencies.

Domestic manufacturers face intense competition from low-cost imports. To compete effectively, they must offer premium quality products, requiring substantial investment in facilities. Reliance on yearly contracts complicates the establishment of a client base.
factors_decreased_barrier: The low market concentration level decreases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Competitive pricing attracts customers in the low-margin metal pipe and tube industry.
Manufacturers must offer a variety of high-quality products to stay competitive.
Balancing cost and quality is crucial for maintaining market position.
Having a diverse product line at various price points is crucial.
Low-cost imports continuously threaten domestic manufacturers' profits. Offering a range of products helps mitigate this threat and sustain profitability in a competitive market.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Since this industry encompasses dozens of different products intended for a wide range of markets, no single company dominates the entire industry.
Instead, most manufacturers develop positions in niche markets.

Still, several metal pipe and tube manufacturers have a considerable influence over a specific product segment or market. For example, a small number of successful companies dominate the oil and gas markets.

The waterworks and industrial segment including machinery manufacturing, pulp and chemical processing is highly fragmented. These markets often prioritize regional markets rather than interacting globally.

These companies are often highly specialized, limiting entrants and adding to concentration. Successful companies have increasingly targeted smaller competitors with strong contracts with downstream buyers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Raw material prices, notably steel, are the largest expense for metal pipe and tube manufacturers. Purchases include steel sheets, rods, dies, other molds and raw nonferrous metals.

Purchase cost fluctuations have created significant revenue volatility, weakening profit. Lower order volumes caused lower manufacturing capacity utilization rates amid the pandemic, making overhead costs more burdensome.
Despite technological innovations, metal tube and pipe manufacturing remains labor-intensive compared to other metal product manufacturers. Small companies, too, are more reliant on labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Metal pipe and tube manufacturing is labor-intensive. Manufacturers require skilled workers to operate complex machinery.
The industry is increasingly capital-intensive, relying on advanced machinery and automation. Higher capital expenses stem from the need to invest in new technologies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Environmental Policy Hinders Downstream Oil and Natural Gas Markets
volatility_points.volatility_description: Metal pipe and tube manufacturing exhibits a high level of revenue volatility. Revenue fluctuates in response to demand from downstream oil and gas industries and the oil and gas price index.

Metal pipe and tube manufacturers rely on inputs, primarily steel and iron, to create products for various buyers. Manufacturers often pass higher costs onto consumers, stressing profit but generating greater per-unit revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Technological innovations have streamlined the manufacturing process
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturing technology, although skilled labor remains crucial to operating complex equipment.

Improvements in coating processes have made regular carbon steel pipes and tubes more resistant to corrosion. These improvements help manufacturers limit waste, save on purchase costs and increase selling prices due to quality enhancements.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports increase competition for domestic companies. The effects of cheap imports have been reduced as a result of tariffs.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Industry products are used for infrastructure projects. As the US economy improves, industry revenue is expected to increase as industrial investment increases.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Declines in oil and steel negatively affect the industry. Both commodities often endure volatility.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Generally, companies locate themselves close to oil and gas operators, with Texas being the industry's primary operating location.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Automation allows companies to mitigate labor costs. Production processes are increasingly being automated, however, take a long time to implement.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: 3D printing is not generally used for metal pipes. Companies are investing in new production methods to increase strength and durability.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies must comply with EPA regulations or else face large fines and possible lawsuits. Environmental regulations are strict for the industry.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: Environmental lawsuits have the potential to impact profitability. Required environmental upgrades of machinery or processes can result in untimely expenses for companies, hurting profitability.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is largely determined by activity in the oil and gas and utilities sectors. More diversified companies tend to have more stable profit margin over time.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? Is your technical expertise to a world standard?
FAQs.answer: Access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques. Investment in new, cost-lowering capital equipment helps maintain or improve competitiveness.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: Economies of scale ensure that the cost per unit of output decreases as scale increases, thereby boosting a company's profitability. As industry products are generally capital intensive and industry niche, companies try to prioritize certain market segments to boost overall demand.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members? What has been members' response to the increases?
FAQs.answer: Companies need to be able to pass on movements in steel prices to protect their own margins. Price competition from other operators have also prevented operators from passing on costs to consumers.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue depends on the Oil Drilling and Gas Extraction industry? What are some other ways to boost demand?
FAQs.answer: As the oil and natural gas price index increases, oil and gas exploration increases as extraction operations become more profitable. As oil and gas exploration increases, demand for industry products will rise.

FAQs.question: How has the current value of utilities construction affected your company? How can you take advantage as the value increases? Are certain products more heavily affected by this value?
FAQs.answer: Aging sewage and water supply infrastructure has led to increased investment in infrastructure upgrades and replacements by municipalities. As sewage and water supply systems are updated and maintained, demand for industry products will increase.

FAQs.question: How has volatility in the price of steel affected your cost of goods sold? How can you mitigate that cost?
FAQs.answer: Generally, an increase in the price of steel benefits the industry, as it indicates increasing downstream demand.
